title: 109_hr450
content: The Act may be cited as the "National Science Education Incentive Act of 2005". The Congress emphasizes the importance of maintaining the US's position in science and technology for advancing human understanding and improving lives. Over half of the country's economic growth is attributed to research and development in these fields, with fundamental research exploring the universe and applied research addressing everyday problems. The United States needs to focus on education to promote economic growth by developing intellectual capital in the form of scientists, engineers, technologically proficient workers, and scientifically literate voters and consumers. This is crucial for the country's competitiveness and innovation in a science-based, high-technology workplace. The United States must improve K-12 science and mathematics education to compete globally. New teaching methods, curricula, teacher training, and parental involvement are needed. Science education should focus on inquiry, experiments, and concepts. Science education should be object-oriented, experiment-centered, and concept-based, starting at an early age and continuing throughout school. Teachers play a crucial role in connecting students with the content they are learning, and high-quality, well-trained teachers are essential. Incentives for teachers to remain in the classroom and improve their practice, along with ongoing training, are necessary for superior results. Teachers need to be knowledgeable about their content area, curriculum, up-to-date research, and effective teaching techniques. Teachers need to be knowledgeable about their content area, curriculum, up-to-date research, and effective teaching techniques to connect information to their students in the classroom. SEC. 3. Refundable credit for portion of tuition paid for undergraduate education of certain teachers. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to include a new section for tuition assistance for teachers pursuing undergraduate education. In general, eligible teachers can receive a tax credit of 10% of qualified undergraduate tuition paid, up to $1,000 per year. Teachers in high-needs school districts may receive up to $1,500. The credit is only available for the first 10 years of teaching. Eligibility is based on specific criteria. The tax credit is available for eligible teachers who are full-time teachers in grades K-12, teaching math, science, engineering, or technology courses. Middle or secondary school teachers must have a relevant degree from an institution of higher education. The tax credit is available for eligible teachers with a baccalaureate degree in mathematics, science, engineering, or technology from an institution of higher education, who are highly qualified. School administrative functions can be considered teaching courses if they relate to such courses. Qualified undergraduate tuition refers to higher education expenses for enrollment at an institution of higher education. The text chunk discusses the definition of an institution of higher education and the regulations that the Secretary shall prescribe. It also includes conforming amendments to the Internal Revenue Code. The text chunk discusses tax amendments related to tuition for certain teachers and overpayments of tax, with effective dates specified. Additionally, it introduces credits for contributions benefiting STEM education at the elementary and secondary school level. The text chunk introduces a tax credit for STEM contributions at elementary and secondary schools, including school contributions, teacher externship expenses, and teacher training expenses. STEM school contributions consist of property and service contributions. The tax deduction for charitable contributions of STEM inventory property to elementary or secondary schools has specific criteria for eligibility, including the donee being a school within the U.S., the property being used for educational purposes related to the school's function, the property fitting into the school's education plan, and restrictions on transferring the property for monetary gain. The term 'STEM service contributions' refers to payments made for STEM services provided in the U.S. or defense dependents' education system for students at specific schools. Taxpayers must be in the business of providing these services without charging for them. 'STEM inventory property' is defined as contributions to schools for educational purposes. The term 'STEM inventory property' refers to property donated to schools for STEM education in grades K-12. 'STEM services' are services provided to schools for STEM education, including teaching courses in science, technology, engineering, or mathematics. The 'defense dependents' education system' is the program established under the Defense Dependents' Education Act of 1978. The term 'STEM teacher externship expenses' refers to amounts paid for STEM teachers to participate in training programs in science, technology, engineering, or mathematics. These programs are established by businesses to enhance teaching skills and knowledge in STEM areas. The term 'STEM teacher training expenses' refers to amounts paid for eligible STEM teachers in grades K-12 to participate in training programs in science, technology, engineering, or mathematics. Teachers must be employed at educational organizations in the US or on US military bases, with teaching responsibilities in STEM subjects. The curr_chunk discusses the denial of double benefits for deductions under the tax code related to STEM teacher training programs. It also includes conforming amendments to the tax code to incorporate the elementary and secondary STEM contributions credit. The curr_chunk discusses contributions benefiting STEM education at the elementary and secondary school level. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years after the enactment of the Act. Additionally, the Act ensures continued local control over educational institutions and school systems.
